title: coronavirus-phase-3-seven-new-things-can---gyms-update-revealed
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has today outlined a further easing of lockdown measures in Scotland.Giving her three-weekly update to the Scottish Parliament, the First Minister set out some key changes to the route map out of lockdown.However, Ms Sturgeon confirmed that the country would not yet be moving into Phase .It comes as Scotland is currently dealing with a number of coronavirus clusters, and with schools having reopened to pupils last week.Driving lessons can resume from MondayLast month, the First Minister outlined a series of indicative dates for further changes to the lockdown rules, which she confirmed today.As of Monday, the following things will be permitted:Live eventswith physical distancing, enhanced hygiene and restricted numbers following relevant guidance.Organised outdoor contact sports can resume for all ages, following the guidance of relevant sports bodies.Snooker  pool halls and indoor bowling facilities can re-open ndash following guidance.Bingo halls can re-open with physical distancing and following guidance.Driving lessons can resume ndash following guidance.Amusement arcades and casinos can re-open following guidance including enhanced hygiene.Funfairs - both static and travelling - can re-open subject to relevant guidance.The First Minister also provided an update on gyms and other events.Gyms and swimming pools can now reopen from August .Indoor sports courts can also open from that date.

title: a68-closure-bear-scotland-hopes-september-reopening
story: WORKS to repair the A are expected to last until early September.As previously reported, a stretch of the road is currently closed following a landslide near Falaon Wednesday, August .And transport bosses today confirmed the time-frame for fixing the flood-damaged route.:A damage: Herersquos the ersion routeAndy Thompson, BEAR Scotlandrsquos south-east representative, said: ldquoWe now have a detailed programme for the remainder of these works.ldquoWersquove considered how to minimise the timescale for each step and are optimistic that we can reopen the A by early September, barring further severe weather or unforeseen issues.ldquoThe repair is being carried out in three phases.ldquoWersquove already made good progress on the first phase stabilising the site, erting utilities and putting down initial layers of stone.ldquoIn the second phase we will complete the ,-tonne rock infill to bring the collapsed embankment up to road level."The final phase is to complete the rebuild of the road itself, including reinstatement of the roadside barrier, drainage and lining.ldquoIrsquom grateful to road users and local communities for their patience while these works continue.ldquoPlease rest assured we are doing everything in our power to get the A reopened as soon as possible and to minimise the disruption caused.

title: scottish-borders-council-considers-new-20mph-speed-limits
story: SPEED limits could be slashed in the Borders from next month.Councillors are being asked to rubber-stamp plans to cut mph zones down to mph in  communities.The move is part of an -month pilot to encourage more Borderers to walk and cycle.The scheme will be discussed at a meeting of the full council next Thursday.Councillor Gordon Edgar, executive member for roads and infrastructure, said: ldquoCoronavirus has changed the way we live and move around, and as a result we felt this was the perfect time to work with Sustrans Scotland to try out new measures that may sht the balance towards walking and cycling, which we may not otherwise do.ldquoThis trial will aim to help people in the Borders lead healthier lestyles, and at same time help reduce CO emissions.ldquoIf approved onAugust , the introduction of mph areas will be a hugely signicant change for all of our communities but it is worth emphasising this is a pilot which will be continually reviewed throughout its -month duration.The proposals come after the council secured pound. million from the Spaces for People programme, funded by the Scottish Government.Mr Edgar added: ldquoThe council is planning to work with a Scottish university to ensure an academic evaluation of the Spaces for People programme is carried out, which will show which of these temporary measures were successful, which were not, and which need to be improved.The local authority is already trialling mph zones in some areas.Among them are the C road between Lauder and Earlston the Innerleithen to Peel route the B between Peebles and Traquair and the C between Heriot and Clovenfords.Karen McGregor, director of Sustrans Scotland, said: ldquoItrsquos clear that people across Scotland want to do the right thing during coronavirus. They want to look after their physical and mental health.ldquoThey also want to make sure that they are keeping to physical distancing guidelines while still being safe on our streets.ldquoProviding funding support to Scottish Borders Council through our Spaces for People programme will make it easier and safer for Borderers to travel around their area for essential travel and exercise.

title: coronavirus-scotlands-schools-pupils-staff-tested-positive
story: Pupils across Scotland headed back to the classroom last week for the first time since schools closed their doors due to the coronavirus pandemic in March.Less than one week since their , several schools across the country have recorded one or more positive cases of coronavirus in either pupils, staff orpeople connected to their institutions.During that time, schools in Aberdeenshire, Glasgow, Lanarkshire, Perth and Kinross and Renfrewshire have recorded positive cases.Health bosses have stressed that there is currently no evidence of transmission within schools, and cases appear to be from community transmissions.Anywhere that has seen a positive case has been quickly identied and contact tracing has been carried out.Kids and staff have so far been given the all-clear to remain in school and continue to attend, except those who have been identied as close contacts of any affected person.Here are all the schools in Scotland with either pupils, staff or people connected to them who have tested positive.Please note - this list also includes schools where contact tracing is being carried out, but cases have not been confirmed by the local health board. Entries in this category will be identied in pop-out bubbles.

title: rachael-hamilton-scottish-borders-council-must-resume-services
story: A BORDERS MSP has called on Scottish Borders Council to improve the maintenance of town centres and reopen more public toilets.Scottish Conservative MSP Rachael Hamilton made the comments after a tour of Jedburgh with the townrsquos community enhancement group.Mrs Hamilton said: ldquoBorders towns are renowned for their town pride and we cannot let that reputation slip.ldquoWe need to see full council maintenance services resume to get out towns back looking spick and span.Mrs Hamilton said that, as a result of the COVID- pandemic, grass-cutting and other routine maintenance work had not been carried out.The MSP ndash who represents Ettrick, Berwickshire and Roxburgh ndash said drivers are encountering poor visibility at junctions due to the lack of grass-cutting on verges.:Rachael Hamilton: Borders MSP given new party positionShe said: ldquoI want to thank all the volunteers that work hard to ensure that hanging baskets, flower boxes and the general appearance of our towns looks beautul.ldquoWith people visiting the Borders on staycations, we need all of our public lavatories open, as this becomes a serious issue with people who live with medical conditions or have a disability.ldquoWe want our beautul Borders to look its best and have facilities open again.ldquoI urge Scottish Borders Council to resume normal maintenance services so our towns and villages can look beautul again.A council spokesperson pointed out that Jedburgh public toilets are open.They added: ldquoA number of key toilets were reopened last month in towns and at popular tourist destinations which normally see high usage. The list of facilities can be found via www.scotborders.gov.uk coronavirusldquoDue to the need to keep the public and our staff as safe as possible, a signicantly increased cleaning and hygiene programme is in place at these facilities.ldquoThis has required an increased level of resources to be dedicated to public toilets and means we have decided to use a phased approach to the reopening of these facilities.ldquoNo further public toilet facilities will be opened at this time.

title: countryside-kitchens-borders-firm-creates-jobs-kelso
story: A BORDERS business has created four jobs with the opening of a workshop in Kelso.Countryside Kitchens, which has an office in Swinton and a showroom in Edinburgh, had outsourced the manufacturing of its cabinets to a company in Yorkshire for  years.But the family firm, which celebrates its th anniversary next month, has decided to take full control of its own work.Four new staff start on Mondayat the companyrsquos new workshop at Pinnacle Hill industrial estate in Kelso ndash and more jobs may be created in the future.Design director Shona Ponder, who owns and runs the business with husband and finance director Jerry, said: ldquoHaving our own workshop is an exciting step and really feels like we are enhancing out status as a company in the Borders."We are taking on four new people and hope to take on more in the future."This move allows us to follow through our orders from start to finish by giving us complete control."It means we can manage the timetable of all projects without relying on someone .The couples son Elliot will be in charge of the workshop, while daughter Susie recently came on board as design technician, looking after IT and computer aided design ldquoThis is a big step for us and very exciting, said Elliot, who was previously involved in the design side of the business.ldquoItrsquos a great opportunity grow the business."We can now welcome trade enquiries from architects, builders and joiners as well as our traditional customers.

title: hawick-welcome-initiative-helps-visitors-town
story: FORMER Hawick Cornet John Hogg teamed up with tourist guides this week to promote the town to visitors.It was part of the #ScotlandStartsHere Borders campaign which is emphasising the benefits of staycation tourism.Mr Hogg was joined by fellow welcome hosts Niamh Scott and Amy Hope-Wilson.Marjorie McCreadie of the Hawick Welcome Initiative, a body set up to fund the project, said: "The four hosts we had prior to lockdown have secured other jobs, so I was in a tight spot but all is well.ldquoI am delighted and relieved that the three of them have come forward.Amy, , was pleased to see the town bustling with visitors when she started meeting and greeting last weekend.She said: ldquoWersquove been really busy. The sun has been out and wersquove had a lot of English people coming over the border, which is good for the town.Niamh, , has just left high school and is taking a year out until the coronavirus pandemic subsides.She added: ldquoThis role is new for me, but Irsquove enjoyed it and itrsquos been quite surprising. With everything that goes on, I didnrsquot expect it to be so busy.The girls are splendidly decked out in matching Hawick Tartan skirts, cravats and face coverings to match when they go into shops.Marjorie praised local businesses for helping to get unorms and the scheme up and running again.Welcome hosts are tasked with assisting visitors and provide them with information on where to eat, sleep, shop and make the most of their time in the town.They are paid by Hawick Welcome Initiative, who access money through Scottish Borders Council, the common good fund and general fundraising.Now operating from Monday to Saturday, am to pm, until September , the welcome hosts are concentrating on the area between the Common Haugh and the horse.Hawick Provost Watson McAteer said: ldquoThe sight of two young welcome hosts speaking and directing visitors on the High Street is evidence that Hawick is ing to some form or normality with local traders hopefully seeing a change in their economic fortunes.ldquoItrsquos great to see the town bustling with tourists. The hosts dressed in their Hawick Tartan is certainly a reassuring sign for visitors and locals alike.

title: borders-tourism-melrose-abbey-reopens-visitors
story: MELROSE Abbey reopened to the public this week.The iconic Borders landmark was forced to close its doors in March due to the coronavirus pandemic.But visitors can now head back ndash as long as they book in advance.A spokesperson said: "A number of new safety and hygiene measures will be in place at the site, which is operated by Historic Environment Scotland ."Tickets must be booked in advance. On-site cash payments are no longer being accepted for the foreseeable future and visitors are being asked to use contactless payment where possible."Capacity will also be reduced on site one-way systems will be in place and access to small enclosed spaces, such as the Bell Tower and Sacristy, will be restricted."Visitors will be also be required to wear face coverings when entering the retail shop, in line with Scottish Government guidance."For more information, visit: historicenvironment.scot reopening

title: call-extend-20mph-limit-past-seton-sands
story: East Lothian Council has introduced lower speed limits in many towns and villages ndash including Cockenzie and Port Seton ndash as part of a project to make the streets safer for pedestrians and the increased number of cyclists who are being seen out and about.It is also creating a temporary cycle path between Cockenzie and Port Seton and Prestonpans which will run along the north side of the B coast road.Community councils in these areas have welcomed these changes, which were announced after the local authority received pound.million in funding from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Spaces for People initiative.However, Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council has called for its mph road speed limit to be extended to include the section of the B at Seton Sands Holiday Village, to the immediate east of Port Seton, which has been the scene of tragic road accidents in the past.Bryan Hickman, community council chairman, said while some concerns had been raised on social media about the money being spent on measures and their temporary nature, the majority of people commenting supported the changes.He said: ldquoMost people, including the community council, are in agreement. Any work that makes the roads safer for pedestrians and cyclists must be welcomed and supported.ldquoIt is felt, however, that the mph zone needs to be extended beyond Seton Sands holiday camp.ldquoThis stretch of road is very prone to speeding and has had a number of accidents, some unfortunately fatal.Brian Weddell, chairman of Prestonpans Community Council, said they, along with neighbouring community councils in Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry, had been campaigning for lower speed limits around their communities.And he said the introduction of the three-metre wide cycle lane on the coast road would be welcomed by cyclists and motorists alike.He said: ldquoWith the huge increase in cyclists on our local roads and shoppers having to queue on pavements measures aimed at slowing the speed of traffic in the town are to be welcomed.ldquoThe three community councils in the Preston Seton Gosford ward have been campaigning to get speed limits lowered on the roads around the local towns and villages and hopefully this will also be introduced by East Lothian Council.ldquoThe dedicated cycle route between Prestonpans and Cockenzie will be particularly welcomed by local children who have taken to their bikes during the pandemic. The two-way cycle path will also be appreciated by motorists who have been getting frustrated at the signicant increase of cyclists using the coast road.Additional plans under Spaces for People include installing, in the autumn, electric bike hire stations featuring eight e-bikes at two locations in Prestonpans and one in Cockenzie in autumn.

title: broadband-improvements-lined-towns
story: Openreach wants to make ultra-reliable and gigabit-capable full fibre broadband available to places throughout Scotland, including Cockenzie and Port Seton, Prestonpans, Tranent, Belhaven and Dunbar.It is hoped having access to some of the fastest broadband speeds in Europe will boost post-Covid economic recovery.Robert Thorburn, Openreachrsquos partnership director for Scotland, was pleased to see work progressing.He said: ldquoWersquove already upgraded hundreds of thousands of homes and business across Scotland to full fibre.ldquoAs well as keeping the existing network running throughout the Covid- crisis, our engineers have, safely and with social distancing in place, continued building the new infrastructure to make sure that as lockdown restrictions ease, our network is there to support families, businesses and the economic recovery.Work is expected to get under way in many of the announced locations within the next - months, although, due to the size of the build, some places will see work continue into .Paul Wheelhouse MSP, the Scottish Governmentrsquos connectivity minister, said: ldquoDigital Connectivity has played a vital role in supporting our efforts to keep people safe and connected during lockdown, and will play a pivotal role in plans for our strategic economic recovery from the pandemic, maintaining jobs and livelihoods and creating new skills and opportunities.ldquoThis rollout of gigabit-capable full fibre broadband access enabled by Openreach to these more rural areas is welcomed.To view the full list of market towns and villages included in the announcement, go to www.openreach fibre-broadband

title: changes-planned-high-street-scotmid-store
story: The High Street supermarket is looking to make changes inside its store, while also increasing the number of spaces in the neighbouring car park.Proposals for the store and car park are being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.A spokeswoman for the business said they had discussed the project with the local community council ahead of submitting the planning application.She said: ldquoThe work being proposed will help improve our offer in the community by improving the store entrance and external appearance of the store and by refitting the store in accordance with our latest branding.ldquoWe also recognise the limitations of the existing car park and propose to make our car park larger and easier to access.ldquoWe also propose to move the funeral unit which is located in the car park into the main building.The number of spaces in the car park will nearly double as it increases from  to .Some work has already been carried out inside the store, with energy efficient refrigeration cabinets with doors installed.

title: redundancy-talks-musselburgh-racecourse
story: In a move described by union officials as a ldquoworrying indication for the future, talks with a number of staff are being held.It is understood that three of the five ground staff who look after the course are being axed, leaving just two and the head groundsman.Racecourse manager Bill Farnsworth confirmed that redundancy talks were being held and pointed to the devastating impact of Covid- on the industry and Musselburghrsquos operations.However, GMB Scotland, which oversaw negotiations with East Lothian Council and Chester when the local authority brought them in to operate the racecourse, said it believed more options should have been considered.And it questioned how the award-winning course could keep up standardsthe workers involved were reduced so drastically.Benny Rankin, GMB Scotland organiser, said: ldquoWe are doing all we can to assist our members affected by these redundancies but there is no denying itrsquos a worrying indication for the future of this historic racecourse.ldquoWe believe that Chester havenrsquot explored all possible options to protect the employment of the existing workforce, including the use of the Government furlough scheme until its deadline, and this looks like the easy option rather than the right thing to do for the long-term.ldquoWe struggle to see how Musselburghrsquos five-star status can be sustainedsome of the workers who help make it what it is are losing their livelihoods, and it poses questions of the Chester management over their vision for the future of this course.Musselburgh Racecourse was run jointly by East Lothian Council and Lothians Racing Syndicate for more than a decade under the Musselburgh Joint Racing Committee.However, issues within the committee led to the British Horseracing Authority demanding an independent inquiry into its governance, which revealed a toxic relationship had developed between the two parties.The council set up Musselburgh Racing Associated Committeendash a new governance body ndash to oversee it as it sought a third-party operator to take over the management of the course.Staff at the racecourse at that point became council employees.When Chester took over on June , they transferred to the company.Mr Farnsworth said that the course finances had been hit by lockdown and, even when racing resumed behind closed doors, it was with no spectators or hospitality.He said: ldquoIt would be inappropriate to comment on the details but, like every racecourse in the country, we are having to review operational costs across the business in light of the coronavirus pandemic.ldquoThe reality is that since we resumed racing behind closed doors on June , we are a racecourse which is now racing again but without spectators, without hospitality revenues and with reduced sponsorship and media rights income.ldquoThe racecourse is unable to carry on as normal.ldquoLike every other business, be it in the sports, leisure, tourism, retail, professional services or industrial sectors, we are having to review everything we do in order to have a sustainable business, so that we can recover from the coronavirus pandemic.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, described the redundancies as ldquodeeply concerning.He said: ldquoThe change of ownership was meant to secure the course and the jobs, not threaten them.ldquoThese are dficult times but staff have maintained a marvellous facility before and during the crisis.ldquoThey are entitled to be treated better.ldquoIrsquoll be seeking assurances from the new management.

title: betrayal-claim-mcdonalds-musselburgh-recommended-approval
story: In a letter to the Courier, Fraser McAllister hit out at their ldquoillogical recommendation which,approved by councillors at an online meeting next week, would grant permission for a restaurant to be created in the car park of the Tesco store off Olivebank Road.He claimed that the drive-thru, which would operate  hours a day, seven days a week, would be ldquonext to the most congested roundabout in the county.The former SNP councillor for Musselburgh West said: ldquoTragically,  local objectors and , petitioners have less value than the share value of these gigantic corporations.He called on councillors on the planning committee, which will debate the proposal on Tuesday, to halt the ldquobetrayal.Mr McAllister also lodged a formal objection, citing a range of concerns including traffic congestion, pollution, litter, obesity, residential amenity and economic damage.He claimed: ldquoThe custom predicted for this -hour McDonaldrsquos drive-thru and the intensity of the declared deliveries needed to service it are on an industrial scale. The impact on Olivebank Road would be truly calamitous.The plan will go before a lsquovirtualrsquo meeting of the planning committee after being called off the delegated list by ward councillor Stuart Currie because of the level of local concern.He said: ldquoI have called this application off the list to ensure that all the concerns raised by local residents are discussed and elected members can understand not only the strength of feeling but also the planning issues that exist as a result of this application.Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council has lodged an objection, citing traffic congestion, emissions, and the facilityrsquos close proximity to local schools as concerns.A public campaign lsquoNo McDonaldrsquos in Musselburghrsquo was also launched in a bid to halt the plan, highlighting concerns such as increased traffic congestion, litter and air pollution.The planning report stated that there were  written representations to the application and, of these,  were objections.It said: ldquoThe councilrsquos road services advise they accept the conclusions of the traffic network modelling exercise, that the traffic impact associated with the proposed development would be minimal and there would be no adverse impact on the operation of the local highway network.ldquoMany written objections are made on the grounds of the proximity of the proposed drive-thru restaurant to Musselburgh Grammar School, and that such a facility promotes unhealthy eating and thus would lead to harmful health consequences.ldquoThe East Lothian Local Development Plan  does not contain any policies restricting the location of drive-thru restaurant facilities to a certain distance from schools, or any other educational establishments. Nor does it contain any policies relating to unhealthy eating or the health consequences of proposed developments. Thus, and in the absence of national guidance on health consequences of proposed developments, no signicant weight can be given to these matters.The report added: ldquoOn the matter of air quality, the public health and environmental protection officer advised that the proposed development was anticipated to result in up to  customer vehicles visiting the premises daily, which was a signicant number of additional vehicles given the proximity of site to the Air Quality Management Areaon Musselburgh High Street.The officer agreed with the conclusion of McDonaldrsquos Air Quality Assessment that impacts upon air quality at ldquosensitive receptors would not be signicant. The officer advised that, whilst it was acknowledged that additional traffic would have an impact upon queuing and reduce traffic speeds, the composition of the increased traffic would be from passenger cars, which are less polluting than HGVs and buses.The officer concluded that the proposed development would have ldquono harmful impact on air quality nor on the objectives of the AQMA and would not harm the amenity of the area.A McDonaldrsquos spokesperson said: ldquoWe look forward to progressing with this application and believe a new McDonaldrsquos would bring signicant investment to the local community, as well as create at least  new jobs.A supporting statement from the company added: ldquoThere are few restaurants in the country who can claim to have made so many positive changes to support healthier lestyles. McDonaldrsquos believe that the lessons they have learned in making these changes can be used to support a wider drive to reduce obesity.Planners are recommending the plan be approved with a number of conditions, including submission of litter and pest management plans.A council spokesperson declined to comment, saying the planning committee would consider the application next week.

title: coronavirus-forces-postponement-brunton-pantomime
story: Theatre organisers were looking forward to presenting the family favourite Aladdin during the festive period.But they have taken the ldquoextremely dficult decision to postpone the show until .A Brunton spokesperson said: ldquoThe Brunton is closely following Government advice as it becomes available.ldquoThe importance of having socially distanced measures in place once live performances are able to take place again will be crucial for the safety of our customers, staff, cast and freelance creative team.ldquoThese measures will mean that the audience size for live performances at The Brunton will be vastly reduced."The live interactive family experience which The Brunton panto delivers will also be affected.Last years pantomime was Cinderella.Michael Stitt, chairman of The Brunton Theatre Trust, said: ldquoIt is with great sadness that we announce the postponement of our  pantomime.ldquoThe Brunton panto is a much-loved tradition that is central to many peoplersquos festive celebrations ndash a tradition that we enjoy bringing to le every year.ldquoWe are aware that, although this is the right decision to take, it affects many ndash the cast, crew, and creatives that make the show every year, The Brunton staff and, of course, our wonderful audiences who join us to shout out at the baddies and laugh along with the dame.ldquoSo letrsquos think of it merely as a postponement, not a cancellation, of our treasured panto. Aladdin will be with us bigger and better for the festive season .ldquoThank you from everyone at The Brunton for your continued support and understanding.Aladdin will run from November , , until December , . Tickets will be available at thebrunton

title: preston-athletic-players-swap-boots-bicycles-fundraiser
story: Members of Preston Athletic FCrsquos squad got on their bikes to raise money for the club and the NHS on Saturday, August .A dozen players, as a relay team, cycled from Dunbar Unitedrsquos New Countess Park through East Lothian, Midlothian and Edinburgh before reaching the finish line at their home ground, the Pennypit.Kai Austin was among those setting off from the Seasidersrsquo ground at about am but had to make a quick substitution before kick-off.He said: ldquoI had not checked my bike for about a week beforehand.ldquoI was putting it into the car and noticed the back tyre was flat.ldquoI thought we would pump it up when we got there.ldquoAfter we arrived, my girlfriend drove away and I was walking along and noticed the tyre was flat again.Fortunately, one of Kairsquos team-mates for the cycle had a spare bike and they were quickly able to get on the open road.The fundraiser came about with players deciding to visit  football grounds ndash the home of  teams ndash ahead of the   season.The first stop was at Millfield , before going on to Foresters Parkand New Recreation Park .The second group of cyclists ventured into Midlothian and ticked off Kingrsquos Park , Newbattle Complex , New Victoria Park , Newbyres Park , New Dundas Parkand Ferguson Park .Nathan Stokes, who plays in midfield and up front, was among the third group, who completed the Midlothian section by travelling on to Penicuik Park .Then it was into the Capital and Paties Road , Meggetland , Saughton Enclosureand Christie Gillies Park .Finally, the Edinburgh section was complete with a visit to Ainslie Park Stadium , St Marks Parkand Peffermillbefore ing to East Lothian and Olivebankand the Pennypit.Nathan, , said: ldquoTo get to Peffermill, we came down Cameron Toll.ldquoFrom the Commonwealth Pool, it is all downhill and by that point my legs were screaming.ldquoFor me, it was a nice relaxing run down there and when we reached Peffermill we knew it was only  minutes to Musselburgh and then another - minutes to the Pans. Getting to East Lothian was definitely a psychological boost.The cyclists finished at the Pennypit shortly after pm, where they were met by the participants from the earlier legs.Right-back Kai, who lives just metres from the ground in Prestonpans, was among those at the finish line. He said: ldquoWe had the people that did the cycle and some people there that were not able to do it because of injury.ldquoThe club put on a socially distanced get-together and put on some sausage rolls and pies.ldquoWe were sitting in the stand and were there for them arriving and cheered them in.Nathan, of Wallyford, was delighted to reach the finish line, with the cyclists completing  kilometres over the eight hours.He added: ldquoThe aim was to get pound, and then we raised pound,.ldquoWe are really chuffed and ideally I would like to raise another pound so the cash is split into pound each.ldquoI think I was chuffed and on Saturday Hearts tweeted us and wished us luck.ldquoWe have got a few Hearts fans in the team so they were happy.To support the good cause, go to justgiving crowdfunding prestonathletic

title: changes-planned-musselburgh-promote-social-distancing
story: The plan of action ndash Spaces for People ndash is to ensure physical distancing in streets during the Covid- pandemic, enhancing opportunities for walking and cycling, and easing pressure at key points in the town.East Lothian Council stated: ldquoSupporting safe physical distancing for essential journeys and exercise, we will also improve opportunities for walking and cycling, creating environments that foster healthy and sustainable travel habits.ldquoWe also want to enable the reopening of business without increasing the risk of further infections, to build confidence for visiting local shops and to help stimulate economic recovery.Measures that have been agreed include the removal of parking on the north side of High Street in three areas: four spaces between  and  High Street three spaces between and  High Street and two spaces between  and  High Street.The council stressed that the vast majority of car parking spaces in the town centre would still be available.Pedestrian crossing signals on High Street will also be retimed so the lsquogreen manrsquo appears more frequently.The council added: ldquoPedestrian safety is of paramount importance, especially at a time that schools are ing and workplaces open up. This will be supported through the introduction of mph limits.ldquoUnder a separate programme, two electric bike hire stations, each with eight ebikes, are planned for Musselburgh Railway Station and outside the Brunton Hall.On-road lane markings to emphasise the use of the streets by cyclists are being considered.Also being looked at is the introduction of a bus-and-cycle-only gate and dedicating one carriageway of The Loan, Wallyford, to pedestrians, to make walking to school easier.Ward councillor Stuart Currie said: ldquoCouncillors, traders, community councillors, area partnership members and council officers have met on a number of occasions and there was general agreement on what is being done so far.ldquoThe group will continue to meet to reflect on this and any new issues that come up that may require further interventions, but these will always be discussed with community representatives.Irene Tait, chairperson of Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council, added: ldquoThese are temporary measures that have been put in place to help keep us safe.Barry Turner, of Musselburgh Conservation Society, added: ldquoThe conservation society is supportive of these measures. We welcome efforts being made to make High Street safer at this dficult time.He added: We do have continuing concerns, though, that apart from planters, little is being done to make High Street a more attractive place to spend time, particularly by tackling eyesore buildings which bring a sense of decay and neglect. This will be particularly important post-Covid when the area is likely to be suffering alongside many others from store closures and reduced footfall.ldquoOn the subject of the introduction of a mph zone for the town, this too is to be welcomed. What puzzles us is how the boundaries of the zone were decided upon because some do seem to defy logic. For example, the residents of Inveresk have been crying out for a mph limit and yet the new mph zone comes to an end at the entry point to the village.

title: tributes-paid-north-berwicks-resilience-volunteers
story: In mid-March, the community council launched its action plan, which was operated by a sub-group led by member Sue Northrop, and also comprising chairman Judy Lockhart and secretary Kathryn Smith.It then put out an appeal for volunteers for its resilience team and received hundreds of responses.A Facebook page was set up that kept both volunteers and residents informed, alongside a website with important information.Over the next four months, volunteers assisted in tasks such as picking up prescriptions, delivering shopping, dog walking, cooking meals and buying food.The resilience group also bought and delivered hundreds of copies of the Courier to residents.A Street Links scheme was set up that linked neighbours together and let them know their single point of contact should it be needed a fundraising page was also started which attracted thousands of pounds in donations.Several schemes were also run such as a group of stitchers making masks, a games and jigsaw exchange, and computer tablets being given to vulnerable groups.Judy said: ldquoOn behalf of North Berwick Community Council, I would like to thank everyone who has helped over the past four months volunteering and supportingNorth Berwick Resilience Group.ldquoWe would particularly like to thank the Community Emergency Response Team. The team have each given hundreds of hours of their own spare time to help people in North Berwick, particularly during lockdown but continuously whilst shielders have remained indoors.ldquoOur emergency plan was set upto deal primarily with floods or snowstorms. It tended to involve bringing people together and really prepared us for the exact opposite of a viral pandemic. As a community of volunteers, we had to learn a lot quickly NBCC are incredibly proud of what was achieved and in awe of everyone who helped. On a personal note, the number of people we have helped and all the dferent ways we went about this is something I will never forget being part of.She added: ldquoWe will no longer be buying food and delivering shopping, prescriptions or providing our weekly update in the Courier and delivering hundreds of these throughout the town. However, some of our work will continue, for example the stitchers will continue making masks and we hope to widen our technology project which saw computer tablets being given to vulnerable groups.ldquoWe believe that the work we have begun through the pandemic has helped form a more inclusive North Berwick and we will work to maintain and strengthen that. Thank you for being such an amazing community and we hope in the not too distant future we can all come together again.People who have concerns about shielding, health and social care or property maintenance are asked to call East Lothian Council on  . Those with adult or children wellbeing and social care concerns are asked to call  . Emergency social work concerns out of hours can phone  .For those with Covid- concerns, phone  those looking for help with mental health should call  but press option two. People who need help urgently or in an emergency should call .For all other help and support, call North Berwick Community Centre on   or email nbccinfo@eastlothian.gov.uk

title: tranent-juniors-thank-key-workers-coronavirus-efforts
story: Three sponsor boards will be dotted around the pitch at Foresters Park as a mark of recognition to those doing their bit during the global virus outbreak.David Innes, chairman of the club, felt it was a fitting gesture.He said: ldquoThat was the first thing we thought of doing during the summer.ldquoWe wanted to thank the NHS my we works with them.ldquoA lot of the guys on the committee have friends in the NHS.ldquoIt was a no brainer.The sponsor boards feature a rainbow, with colourful drawings of rainbows appearing in windows theand breadth of the country during the pandemic.The message on the sponsor board reads: ldquoThank you! NHS staff, front-line services, support services and key workers.Mr Innes said that two sponsor boards were already in place at the ground, with plans for a third to be erected.

title: paralympian-maria-lyle-takes-presenting-role-podcast
story: Maria Lyle is not hanging up her running spikes but has teamed up with journalist Gary Heatly to create This Ability Podcast.The monthly show sees the duo chat with a iety of guests about what it is like living with a disability and shines a light on some amazing achievements.Maria, who has spastic diplegic cerebral palsy, said: ldquoIt is something that I have never done before.ldquoGary approached me with the idea of doing it and highlighting how disabled people live their lives and to make it come across that a disability is not such a negative thing. It is something new and I have really enjoyed it and learning from Gary.The third episode of the podcast is being recorded this month.Each episode has been created during the coronavirus pandemic lockdown, with Gary, Maria and their guests in separate locations and speaking over Zoom.The first episode featured Maria, who lives in Dunbar, and Gary, who is based in Edinburgh, discussing their own personal experiences of living with cerebral palsy.Then, last month, the hosts spoke to actress Amy Conachan, who has appeared in more than  episodes of Hollyoaks as Courtney Campbell.Former Dunbar Grammar School pupil Maria said: ldquoShe was really nice and friendly. It was interesting to hear her story about acting and her journey to television, which has been very successful, and how she deals with her disability.Mariarsquos love of athletics began when she was at Dunbar Primary School, with her mum, Susan, taking a PE lesson.She previously said: ldquoOne day, when I was in about primary four, we had a multi-stage fitness bleep test-type thing to do.ldquoI wasnrsquot any good at anything and everything and I wasnrsquot looking forward to it at all ndash even though my mum was the teacher. Running at that stage usually ended with me falling over  per cent of the time and cutting my knees.ldquoBut I thought I would have a go and basically I was the last pupil standing at the end of the test.Since then, she has won medals at the Paralympics in Rio de Janeiro in  and two gold medals at the World Para Athletics Championships in Dubai last year, in the T m and m.The -year-old was due to represent Great Britain at the Paralympics in Tokyo this month before the international event was put back a year due to the coronavirus.She said it was nice to speak to people outside the sporting world about their lives and was looking forward to welcoming more guests onto the podcast.Gary, , who was previously editor of The SCRUM Magazine, praised Mariarsquos efforts on the new podcast. He said: ldquoShe has been absolutely brilliant.ldquoThe first podcast was just me and her having a chat about our own experiences. We are  years apart so we have dferent experiences.To listen to the podcast, go to play.acast s this-ability-podcast

title: youngster-calls-playpark-brought-back-use
story: A padlock and chain are across the gate at the playpark on Dunbarrsquos Wilson Road, with weeds more than a foot tall poking through the bark chips.It is unclear when the park, which is owned by a third party, could reopen, with youngsters forced to leave the street to find a similar playpark.It is a similar situation on neighbouring Wilson Place, with the playpark again off limits.Ten-year-old Eva McCandlish, who attends Dunbar Primary School, made a plea to the Courier to ldquosave our park before it is too late, with the park having been out of use for more than a year.She said: ldquoOur park has become extremely overgrown with weeds, an eyesore for the rest of our street.ldquoBut the weeds arenrsquot the only problem. The park has been unusable for years because some of the items are just not safe.ldquoI have a three-year-old sister, Ailsa, who has never been able to play in the park due to the circumstances, even though she has to walk past it every single day.ldquoIt is just cruel to tell young children that they are not allowed to play in the park opposite them.ldquoAlso, myself, my brother Rory and most of the children on our street have not been able to play safely in our park for most of the time living on our street.In the meantime, the upkeep of the park is not being carried out.Paint is flaking off the playground equipment, while rubbish also sits in the bin.Graham Adams, vice-chairman of Dunbar Community Council, lives on Wilson Road and said the land had been sold on by the developer.He said: ldquoIt would be usedit was in a fit state.The community council has taken the issue up with East Lothian Council, while the problem has been highlighted by local homeowners.Malcolm Payton, chairman of Kingrsquos Meadow Ownersrsquo Association, said it was an issue which had been ongoing for a number of years.He said: ldquoThe developer originally owned the land and it has now been sold on in inidual packets.ldquoDferent people own the dferent playparks.ldquoMy understanding is they have a responsibility for maintaining them and should be maintaining them but they have not been maintaining them and put a padlock onto them to stop people from accessing them.Mr Payton confirmed the issue had been highlighted to the local authority but there seemed to be little progress.A spokeswoman for the local authority confirmed it was not a council maintained playpark.The park also does not fall under a site that would be covered by the health and safety department and the council would have ldquono remit to close it off or enforce clear-up or maintenance of equipment.

title: new-group-tackling-issues-river-esk
story: The Esk River Improvement Groupwas set up following concerns about mine water discharge, sewage, and discharge from combined sewage overflows.Its first meeting, held online last week, was hosted by local MSP Colin Beattie.The discussion was attended by key stakeholders such as the Scottish Environment Protection Agency , Scottish Water, the Coal Authority, East Lothian Council and community councillors, amongst other interested bodies.Mr Beattie said: ldquoThe issues with the River Esk have been ongoing for a long time and I know that my constituents are frustrated that no permanent solutions have been found.ldquoI wanted to establish a group where we look at the overall health of the River Esk and bring together those who are already working to make improvements to the quality of the water. It is much easier to see a result when we are all working collectively to resolve an issue and that is the exact purpose of this forum.ldquoIt is important to me that members of the community are involved and I am pleased we have many representatives from our community councils working with the group, and also some local establishments such as Newbattle Abbey College and Musselburgh Racecourse. It is heartening that so many people are willing to commit to volunteering their time to make active change on this matter.He added: ldquoI was pleased to discuss what progress was being made on these matters already, as well as thinking forward to establish what we need to do to stop these issues arising again in the future.ldquoAll constituents also have a part to play by ensuring they understand what not to flush down the toilet and by helping to educate others. Lessening the amount of sewage debris, which is often full of flushed wipes and sanitary towels, is an essential part in maintaining the cleanliness of the river.ldquoI am very pleased that the Coal Authority are putting in place a system to clean the mining discharge from Junkiersquos Adit, and also that Scottish Water, supported by SEPA, are actively working to undertake clean-ups on the Esk and improve their existing systems to prevent sewage spills going forward.ldquoI would like to remind my constituents that this group is not a substitute for reporting issues, and thatconstituents see pollution in the river then they should report this urgently to SEPA via their pollution reporting tool at www.sepa.org.uk EnvironmentalEvents or get in touch with Scottish Water directly, either through their website or by calling   .ldquoConstituents have a vital role to play by reporting problems when they see them, which allows them to be investigated more quickly and this will allow Scottish Water to undertake urgent clean-up.ldquoAnyone who would like to know more about the group is welcome to contact me at colin.beattie.msp@parliament.scot and I will gladly add them to ERIGrsquos mailing list.

title: nearly-50-m-co-stores-shut-haddington-musselburgh-survive
story: The company, which has been in Haddington for more than  years and in Musselburgh for more than , had appointed administrators in April as the coronavirus outbreak forced the closure of most UK retailers for nearly four months.Positively, Haddingtonrsquos Court Street store and Musselburghrsquos High Street branch have survived.Andy McGeoch, MCorsquos chief executive, said: ldquoIt quickly became clear that the best way to save most jobs and most stores was to enter administration, with a new company acquiring the assets of the old business, and this process has now been finalised.ldquoCovid has been by far the biggest challenge our family business has faced in almost  years, and I am really pleased that we have been able to maintain a presence in over  communitiesldquoCovid- means many people donrsquot feel comfortable travelling on public transport or visiting busy city centres and that can be good news for local High Street stores like MCo.ldquoThatrsquos why we are looking at ways of working in partnership with other local retailers to highlight the tremendous range of shopping that can be found in communities like this all over the country.The administration process, which is being managed by Deloitte, will see the number of MCo stores drop from  to .About  people are being made redundant from a total workforce of more than ,.The Musselburgh store has seven members of staff, with the Haddington branch employing  people neither store is affected by the restructuring.

title: 20-miles-per-hour-speed-limit-introduced-kellie-road
story: All the roads in the Hallhill area of Dunbar have a mph speed limit, with the exception of Kellie Road.Campaigners have repeatedly called for the road, which links Spott Road and the Lochend campus of Dunbar Primary School, as well as Hallhill Sports Centre, to have a reduced speed limit, rather than the mph limit currently in place.The move has consistently been resisted by East Lothian Council, which earlier this year pointed to a survey which said that  per cent of the respondents were against the idea of bringing in a lower speed limit. But now the speed limit could be lowered as part of the measures being weighed up by the council as the county comes out of lockdown.A spokeswoman for the local authority said: ldquoWe are implementing a number of temporary changes in Dunbar as we come out of lockdown.ldquoThis is in order to create physical distancing in streets as daily le is restored, as childrento school and workplaces open.ldquoSupporting this, we will also improve opportunities for walking and cycling, creating environments that foster healthy and sustainable travel habits.Traffic calming measures will be installed on roads throughout the town to enforce the widespread  miles per hour limit.Among the measures being considered is the lowering of the speed limit on Kellie Road, which, it is claimed, would ldquoimprove conditions for cyclists, while a park and stride would be created at the sports centrersquos car park.Other options include closing Hospital Road to traffic to increase space and improve safety for cycling and walking.Back Road could also become a one-way system to create more space for pedestrians.Meanwhile, Countess Crescent could be closed to traffic ndash retaining access to Blue Badge parking ndash while the road on Lammermuir Crescent and Countess Road could be narrowed, as could Belhaven Road and Summerfield Road.

title: plans-prestonpans-town-centre-revealed
story: The measures are being brought in by East Lothian Council under its Spaces for People scheme.It says that due to the limitations on space in the town, it is important that more spaces are introduced for people on foot, in wheelchairs and on bikes.A council spokesperson said: ldquoSupporting safe physical distancing for essential journeys and exercise is vitalwe are to suppress Covid-.ldquoIt will also improve opportunities for walking and cycling, creating environments that foster healthy and sustainable travel habits.Since last month, several new measures have already been introduced to Prestonpans, including a town-wide mph speed limit which also covers Cockenzie and Port Seton.Additional traffic calming measures were also brought in to allow the council to respond to requests for the use of public space, make it easier for people to cross the roadnecessary to maintain social distancing and support walking and cycling to school.Over the next few weeks, more measures will be introduced.On the south-east side of Prestonpans High Street, outside the Filling Station sandwich shop, the pavement will be widened and parking spaces for four cars removed the existing disabled parking space will remain.A three-metre-wide hard-surfaced temporary cycle route will be introduced adjacent to the north-western side of Edinburgh Road, between Prestonpans and Cockenzie.A temporary mph speed limit is also set to be introduced for Edinburgh Road, with regular traffic calming measures along the route.Measures to increase space for pedestrians on busy routes to school and at the school gates are being considered plans include widening pavements.More details on routes to school and the chance for members of the public to comment on them are available at bit.ly afajKcBefore the end of the year, the council hopes to explore the option of installing a public ebike hire station for eight bikes at Prestonpans Community Centre, Prestonpans High Street and in Cockenzie on Edinburgh Road and East Lorimer Place.Fiona OrsquoDonnell, ward councillor, said: ldquoI want to see businesses in our high streets able to operate safely.ldquoThese measures will help them do that with space for people to pass when queues are forming outside.ldquoFeeling they can shop and use other businesses safely will, I hope, encourage more people to use them, keep them open and protect jobs.ldquoThe mph limit will keep us all safer when out and about. I have already seen that it is making it easier for pedestrians to cross the road.ldquoI know it requires a change from drivers, and want to appeal to them to stick to the new limit.Brian Weddell, chair of Prestonpans Community Council, said: ldquoIrsquom very supportive [of the plans], particularly the slowing of traffic as wersquove been campaigning with Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry Community Councils for a couple of years to get traffic speeds reduced entering the villages, so hopefully it will lead to that.He also expressed his support for the cycle path plans.

title: young-people-scotland-can-get-250-free-starting-new-job
story: Its hoped the payment, which is open for applications from today, will help young people with the financial dficulties of starting a new job - including buying new clothes, travel and get childcare.It is estimated around  young people will benefit from the new financial support in its first year.What is the benefit The Job Start Payment is a one-off sum of pound for  to -year-oldsthey have been unemployed for at least six months.The upper age limit rises to  for care leavers and the payment increases to poundthe person has a child.How can I qualy for the payment To qualy for the payment, which will be delivered by Social Security Scotland, the person applying must have received a job offer for paid employment.They must be out of paid work and must have been receiving one of the qualying benefits for six months or more at the time of the job offer:What has the Scottish Government said Social Security Secretary Shirley-Anne Somerville said: ldquoI am delighted that our Job Start Payment is today now open for applications it really couldnrsquot come at a better time to support our young people to take up job offers.ldquoYoung people are among those whose job prospects have been hardest hit by this pandemic. As such, it is crucial that we support them and ensure they are at the heart of our economic recovery from Covid-.She added: ldquoGetting a job can represent a massive turning point for many young people, but it can also bring financial pressures.ldquoCosts like travel, new work clothes, or childcare often have to be met before people get their first pay.ldquoThe brand-new Job Start Payment will help young people with these costs, which can sometimes be a barrier to them taking up an offer, and we will be encouraging anyone eligible to apply.Full details can be found on the Scottish Government website here.

title: say-future-sqa-exams-results-fiasco
story: Last week the Scottish Government made a U-turn due to anger over nearly , results being downgraded from teacher estimates by the SQArsquos controversial moderation system.Those results were later withdrawn, reverting to the original teacher estimates following an outcry from pupils in the form of protests and an online petition, political pressure and threat of a no-confidence vote in Education Secretary John Swinney.Consultation on arrangements for National Courses in - session ndash joint statement from Scottish Government and SQA https:t.co vJgDYfSHCThe SQA website states that ldquoplanning for the  examination diet is underway and will continue, it is important that the education system has plans in place to ensure we can cope with any disruptions.The add that there needs to be ldquoappropriate balance between learning, teaching and assessment in the courses.Following on from the Mr Swinneyrsquos statement, the SQA launched two consultations to gather feedback on modications to qualications and adjustments to the  exam timetable.How can I have my say There are two dferent consultations being run by the SQA.A technical consultation and survey are available on the proposed modications for each course.What is the current  timetable The planned  exam timetable will start on April ,  and finish on June , .What have the Scottish Government said John Swinney said: ldquoCoronavirus has had, and will likely continue to have, an impact on learning, teaching and assessment over the coming year.ldquoI am aware that many teachers will be keen to understand fully the arrangements for the assessment of national qualications in .ldquoThe Education Recovery Group has discussed a number of options in relation to this, and I welcome this consultation exercise by the SQA examining options for possible course modications that could help to support the delivery of learning, whilst maintaining the validity, credibility and standard of qualications.Full details can be found on the SQA website here.

title: renaissance-club-host-scottish-open-start-october
story: The Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open, won last year by Bernd Wiesberger, will be played at The Renaissance Club for the second year.The course, near Archerfield, saw Stacy Lewis crowned as the Ladies Scottish Open winner on Sunday afternoon.The Ladies Open was played without fans and now the menrsquos competition will be played on the same course from October -.It is unknown when professional golf tournaments in the UK and Europe will be able to welcome spectators again.The Scottish Open will be subject to the European Tourrsquos health strategy based on Scottish Government guidelines in Scotland, with more details to be announced in the coming weeks.The tournament was originally due to be played July - before it was pushed back to October - due to the Covid- outbreak.Now, the European Tour has confirmed it will be played seven days earlier and follow on the heels of the Dubai Duty Free Irish Open, with the BMW PGA Championships played the week after the Scottish Open.

title: scotlands-latest-coronavirus-clusters-listed-full---
story: A chicken factory, a fishing vessel and a number of schools have been impacted as a result of the new cases.Commenting on the news, Deputy First Minister John Swinney said: ldquoWhere clusters of cases develop we must find them and act quickly to prevent further spread.But where are the clusters Here, we outline each area and their cases: Perth and Kinross:In Perthshire, the  Sisters food processing plant in Coupar Angus has been closed after four members of staff tested positive for the virus, with a further three workers awaiting results.In addition, there are two connected cases in the community.NHS Tayside said arrangements are being made for testing of employees.Close contacts are being advised to self-isolate and other identied contacts are being followed up and given appropriate advice.There has been an outbreak at the  Sisters factoryAn incident management team is working with the Scottish Government, Public Health Scotland and local environmental health teams to provide advice and support.Meanwhile two cases have been detected in pupils in the area ndash however authorities say there is no evidence of a link to the Coupar Angus cluster.One pupil attends Newhill Primary School in Blairgowrie while the other attends Oakbank Primary School in Perth, and both are currently self-isolating at home with mild symptoms along with their immediate family members.Glasgow:Health officials are also investigating a number of clusters in the central belt.Several coronavirus cases have been identied by pupils in Bannerman High School in the north-east of Glasgow ndash with the latest case involving a pupil who had attended classes.In a letter to parents, carers and pupils, NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde said while none of the cases had been present at the school during the period in which they may be infectious to others up until now, the new case was there during this infectious period.Bannerman High SchoolThe health board said it has undertaken a risk assessment to identy any other pupils and staff this inidual had contact with during this time.These iniduals are being contacted by the Test and Protect team and told to self-isolate.A Glasgow City Council spokeswoman said: ldquoPublic Healthrsquos assessment is that the infection is unlikely to have occurred within the school and is linked to the Baillieston virus cluster.ldquoClose contacts have been notied via test and protect and will be self-isolating for the required number of days and a letter issued on Sunday night to all families, pupils and staff with updated information.PaisleyRenfrewshire Council said on Monday that a case has been confirmed at Todholm Primary School in Paisley.NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde said a problem assessment grouphas systematically established a list of close contacts within the school.Test and Protect staff are now contacting those identied, who are being advised to self-isolate and being given appropriate advice and support.Todholm Primary SchoolRenfrewshire Council said: ldquoWe are following the advice of NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde, who have undertaken a careful risk assessment.ldquoThey are advising there is no current evidence the virus has been transmitted inside the school and that it remains safe for pupils and staff to attend.ldquoThe Test and Protect team are currently contacting any iniduals who have been in close contact with the pupil and advising them to self-isolate at home.ldquoThe health of our pupils and staff is our biggest priority and we will continue to follow the advice of our health service colleagues over how best to protect that.Lanarkshire:Meanwhile, NHS Lanarkshire is carrying out an investigation after three pupils from St Ambrose High School and one from St Andrewrsquos High School, both in Coatbridge, tested positive.A fth case, who is linked to these but is not a pupil, has also been identied.Orkney:In Orkney, the health board said nine positive Covid- cases are now linked to the fishing vessel cluster in Orkney ndash up three from Friday.The new cases are all crew members from the boat and all have been self-isolating.AberdeenIn Aberdeen,  cases have now been confirmed in the city linked to an outbreak discovered in bars and restaurants, while , contacts have been identied.A weekly review is due on Wednesday, two weeks to the day since pubs and restaurants were ordered to close, Aberdonians were told not to visit each otherrsquos houses and restrictions were put on hospital and care home visits as a result of the localised outbreak.The First Minister told herbriefing yesterday: ldquoI think we do see signs, and itrsquos too early to be absolutely definitive about this, the increase in cases in that cluster has decelerated a bit, so it is slowing down.ldquoWe need more time to see whether itrsquos starting to properly reduce in the way we would want it to and I do think the evidence that we have thus far is that Test and Protect has done a very good job.

title: musselburgh-mcdonalds-plan-rejected-east-lothian-council
story: The fast food chain applied for planning permission to build the new restaurant, which would open  hours a day, next to the townrsquos Tesco store as it looked to draw customers from the supermarket into its drive-thru.However, claims by the chainrsquos representative Paula Reed-Smith that the number of visits to the restaurant from Musselburgh Grammar School, on the other side of the supermarket, would be lsquolimitedrsquo were disputed by local councillors.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee met virtually to discuss the plans for land to the east of Inveravon Terrace, off Olivebank Road, and questions were asked about why McDonaldrsquoswas looking to place a drive-thru in a town centre and near a secondary school.Ms Reed-Smith told the committee: ldquoWe anticipate pedestrian visits from the school will be limited.ldquoWe did not choose the location because of Musselburgh Grammar School, we chose it because of the location of Tesco.However, ward councillor Andy Forrest told the committee it would be a short walk to the restaurant for youngsters.He said: ldquoFrom the back door of the school to the front door of the new McDonaldrsquostakes a -second stroll.Councillor Stuart Currie, fellowMusselburgh ward member, who called in the application which was recommended for approval by planning officers, said children would ldquogravitate to the restaurant.He said: ldquoAbout  kids go to Tesco at lunchtime. We will have hundreds of kids walking through Tesco car park to McDonaldrsquos, they will gravitate to it.Musselburgh Area Partnership and Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council both objected to the plans, which drew  objections and two statements of support.Local resident Lynda Baird spoke in favour of the new restaurant, telling the committee that as a mother of four teenage children she welcomed it.She said: ldquoI worked for McDonaldrsquosand the food was always top quality the hygiene standards and training offered is also top quality.Ms Baird also hit back at social media ldquobullies who she claimed had attacked her and anyone who spoke out in favour of the drive-thru on Facebook.She told the committee: ldquoThere has been social bullying of people in support of McDonaldrsquos. I am badly dyslexic and was severely bullied by those against it.ldquoIf you donrsquot want it, donrsquot go, but donrsquot bully people who do want it.But Kirsten Leask, another local resident, urged the committee to reject the McDonaldrsquosapplication, pointing out that the health and wellbeing of children was at the heart of council policy.She said: ldquoThe proposed developmentrsquos location is within walking distance of not just Musselburgh Grammar School but three primary schools.Iain Clark, from the area partnership, also pointed out that three McDonaldrsquosrestaurants near Musselburgh were based out of town centres and away from schools, adding: ldquoWhy should Musselburgh be the exception Bernard Harkins, from the community council, pointed out thatMussselburgh town centre was an Air Quality Management zone because of pollution caused by traffic congestion pre-Covid- lockdown.He said: ldquoDuring lockdown we did see pollution levels fall, with the weekend of May  seeing zero levels recorded. We should be building on that.The councilrsquos roads department came under fire for ruling that traffic attracted by the drive-thru would not have a ldquosignicant impact on current congestion after using a peak hour model to measure it.Councillor Katie Mackie, Musselburgh ward member, said that she had recently timed a drive along theof the road which would be used by the drive-thru and it took her more than five minutes.She said: ldquoI have had more complaints from local residents about this application than any other issue since I was elected in .ldquoThere is no peak hour in Musselburgh town centre, congestion is round the clock.The planning committee voted to go against officersrsquo recommendation and refuse the application on the grounds of its impact on traffic, air quality and noise impact on the amenity of the surrounding residences.

title: former-scotland-striker-garry-oconnor-new-bbc-documentary
story: The striker, who grew up in Port Seton, was tipped as one of Scottish footballrsquos great hopes when he broke into the Hibernian first team as a teenager in .A big money move to Lokomotiv Moscow followed and the frontman would go on to win  caps for Scotland, finding the net four times for his country.However, OConnors career failed to reach the heights that many expected, with off-the-field incidents attracting media attention.Now, the -year-old tells his story in Playing The Game: Garry OrsquoConnor, which is broadcast this evening .The -minute documentary, which is shown on BBC Scotland at pm, looks at him becoming an object of media scrutiny after a failed drugs test and the loss of his fortune.The Easter Road favourite candidly details his struggle with drugs, injuries and money, and provides a unique insight into the glitz, glamour and depression that marked his career.The documentary also features contributions from a range of players and managers connected to OConnors career, including John lsquoYogirsquo Hughes, Donald Park and Ian Murray, who give their perspective on the starrsquos meteoric rise and his dramatic fall.Finally, OConnor, who now lives in North Berwick, acknowledges that he must ignore his critics and focus on his future, including his son Josh, who has started his career by following in his fatherrsquos footsteps and joining the Hibs youth team.
